posts.name: Tucker Stanton
posts.cooked: Hello, recently I have been looking for how to code a soft limit using a rev motor controller and neo motor. The only examples I find are from 2022 when the syntax was different, does anyone have a more recent example I can refer to? Alternatively, I was wondering if there was a built in method to set a soft limit or if I need to continuously get the motor position and check if it does not exceed a certain amount. Any help is appreciated, thank you!

posts.name: Andy Lynch
posts.cooked:

posts.name: James
posts.cooked:
Our robot uses soft limits. You need to create a SparkMotorConfig to create a configuration. Then you input soft limits like this:

Then save the parameters to the SparkMax:

This should all be done in your subsystem constructor. Here is the full link to our code for our elevator subsystem: 2025-Reefscape-Competition/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/ElevatorSubsystem.java at main · FRC3546/2025-Reefscape-Competition · GitHub

posts.name: William Babbitt
posts.cooked: A semi related question, would it be valid to reconfigure at run time? Say if we wanted to have different soft limits at different times in the game or when in different situations?

posts.name: James
posts.cooked: I’m not entirely sure, that sounds like a question for REV. I’m not sure if that is the best idea personally. It sounds safer to me to have a lower and higher limit that stays the entire match and then use pid control to move the elevator to a specific position.

posts.name: Tucker Stanton
posts.cooked: Awesome, thanks! Also out of curiosity because I couldn’t find it on the documentation, is the soft limit parameter measured in rotations?

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
A semi related question, would it be valid to reconfigure at run time? Say if we wanted to have different soft limits at different times in the game or when in different situations?

Yeah, soft limits can be enabled, disabled, or altered at run time. We occasionally use these features, mostly for homing sequences.

However, be mindful here: It’s generally best to set these as the “safety limit” of a system, not the “temporary operational limit”. EG, use them when the expected action of going further causes damage.

The reason is mostly due to the fact that interacting with these is an immediate, uncontrolled stop; The motor just halts, and the system does not otherwise know about it. While you can check this condition on the motor, it’s usually better to ensure that any temporary conditions are simply checked by code in more sensible ways, like reading and acting on the encoder position.

Rev soft limits also do not apply a corrective action. It just blocks action in the prohibited direction. So, when they change dynamically, the system does not otherwise react. What you would need to do is have code (such as a PID ) read the change, clamp your setpoint to the new permitted range, and let it force a system back into compliance.

is the soft limit parameter measured in rotations

It’s measured in whatever units you configured your motor for by using the positionConversionFactor. So, it could be motor rotations, arm rotations, degrees, inches, radians.
